data.title: Project MUSE
data.text:
Erin O’Connor, Associate Professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania, is the author of Raw Material: Producing Pathology in Victorian Culture. Lately, she has been reading a lot of biography.

Theodore Koditschek is Associate Professor of History at the University of Missouri, Columbia. He is the author of Class Formation and Urban Industrial Society: Bradford, 1750–1850, which won the Adams and Schuyler Prizes of the American Historical Association for 1991. He is currently working on a project tentatively entitled: “Towards a Greater Britain: Imperial Romances and the Historical Imagination, 1800–1950.”

Rosemarie Bodenheimer is Professor of English at Boston College. She is the author of The Politics of Story in Victorian Social Fiction and The Real Life of Mary Ann Evans: George Eliot, Her Letters and Fiction, as well as articles on Victorian and modern fiction. She is currently working toward a new book on Dickens and autobiographical storytelling.

Matthew Buckley is Assistant Professor in English at Rutgers University, with specialties in modern drama, media studies, and urban modernity. He is currently working on a book project on the dramatic imagination, social theatricality, and political modernity in revolutionary Europe.

Charles Barker is completing a dissertation on Victorian appropriations of Catholicism at the Johns Hopkins University. His project examines how the eroticized rhetoric associated with Catholic mysticism was deployed in mainstream Protestant representations of marriage and sexuality, workers’ class consciousness, and women’s rights and subjectivities.

Elisabeth Sanders Arbuckle, former Professor of English Literature at the University of Puerto Rico, Rió Piedras, is the author of Harriet Martineau’s Letters to Fanny Wedgwood (1983) and Harriet Martineau in the London Daily News: Selected Contributions, 1852–1866 (1994). She lives in Puerto Rico and is currently working on a biography of Harriet Martineau.

Linda M. Austin, Associate Professor of English at Oklahoma State University, is the author of The Practical Ruskin (1991) and essays on nineteenth-century poetry and prose. Her current project is “Nostalgia and Tradition, 1780–1914.” [End Page 561]

John Bowen is a Reader in the Department of English, Keele University. He is the author of Other Dickens: Pickwick to Chuzzlewit (2000), and a member of the editorial board of the Journal of Victorian Culture. His edition of Barnaby Rudge is forthcoming from Penguin.

Joseph Bristow is Professor of English at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he edits (with Thomas Wortham) Nineteenth-Century Literature. His recent books include two edited collections: The Cambridge Companion to Victorian Poetry (Cambridge, 2000), and Wilde Writings: Contextual Conditions (Toronto, 2002).

Jennifer DeVere Brody, Associate Professor of English and Performance Studies at Northwestern University, is the author of Impossible Purities: Blackness, Femininity and Victorian Culture (1998). Her new book, The Style of Elements: Politically Performing Punctuation, will be published by Duke University Press.

Susan P. Casteras is Professor of Art History at the University of Washington and is the author of scores of books and articles on Victorian visual culture. Currently working on essays for various publications as well as preparing a book on Victorian religious painting, she served for many years as Curator of Paintings at the Yale Center for British Art.

Julie English Early, Associate Professor of English at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, has published on Victorian travel, empire, and women in science. She is working on a book on Edwardian literature and culture and has published related articles in Victorian Studies, Nineteenth-Century Prose, and in Disorder in the Court (1999) and Everyday Violence in Britain (2000). She is also co-editing a collection, “Law, Trials, and the British Cultural Imagination: The Function of the Courtroom at the Present Time, 1830–1930.”

Dino Felluga, Assistant Professor of English at Purdue University, West Lafayette, has published articles that have appeared or will soon appear in SEL, ARIEL, Criticism, European Romantic Review, Victorian Poetry, and the Blackwell Companion to Victorian Poetry. His first book, “The Perversity of Poetry: The Market, Romantic Ideology, and the Male Poet of Genius,” has recently reached completion.
